Yet with all her faults many worse specimens might have been found, even in higher circles than that of "The Doocot." Mrs. Balquidder was very proud of all her children, and not least of this sagacious little Benjamin of hers—to whose wishes she gave in quite amiably on the present occasion.

title: Within a mile o' Edinburgh Town
author: Hardy, Robina F.
snippet: But this, alas! was no time for the sweet dalliance of courtship, as that other hour had been ! They must lose not a minute in letting the joyful truth be known to those anxious searchers and that thronging crowd of onlookers at " The Doocot." A turn in the road had till now served to conceal from Lizzie Fairlie the alarming spectacle, but at last many voices mingling in one hoarse murmur reached her ears, while lights flitting here and there came more prominently into view.

snippet: doubt in the public mind as to whether she had not a title to the more dignified and matronly " Mrs.," and a surname equally uncertain,— for there were vague legends afloat as to Auntie Jean having been married some time or other,—to some man or other,—the hour and the man having alike got lost somehow in the mists of a forgotten past. Auntie Jean therefore resided now in solitary state in a back-room of " The Doocot," close to the shelter of her brother's roof, and where the help of her niece Lizzie could readily be obtained in any emergency such as the present.

title: Within a mile o' Edinburgh Town
author: Hardy, Robina F.
snippet: Tyke and Trudgie—by rights Dennis and Bridget Tiacke—were brother and sister, two little curly-headed creatures of four and five years old, of whose family history little was known—at least at " The Doocot." They were winsome wee things, fortunately for themselves, and their smiling blue eyes, and the funny little nods they bestowed on passers-by, often won a kindly look or word even from the most hurried.

title: Within a mile o' Edinburgh Town
author: Hardy, Robina F.
snippet: They were inseparable friends, and generally " did " their district-visiting together. It was to them that Mr. Bryce usually turned for authentic details concerning the outlying districts, such as " The Doocot," for every man, woman, and child in these hamlets was known to these two faithful visitors.
